awd_titl_txt: EAGER: ISN: Network Analysis and Opportunities for Disruption of Organ Trafficking
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award will contribute to the advancement of national security and welfare through a greater understanding of the worldwide operations of illicit organ trafficking networks. The system of organ trafficking is known to be complex; it consists of multiple players such as kidney sellers (often poor, young and healthy), buyers (affluent but desperate), transplant service providers (surgeons, hospitals and other agents), brokers (who often provide similar services to other illicit trades) and financial institutions that knowingly or unknowingly participate in passing money from the buyers to other actors. Inter-actor social networks are inherent in organ trafficking since the system tends to operate and expand through social connections. This award seeks to establish a fundamental understanding of the network structure, including incentives and behavioral patterns of the participants, linkages between the participants, and its dynamic evolution. The transdisciplinary nature of this project, involving social scientists, operations researchers, and health and health policy professionals, provides an opportunity to examine the nature of organ trafficking networks from multiple perspectives and to discover structural patterns and network disruption strategies that may not be easily discerned otherwise.  The results of this research will be disseminated widely to assist law enforcement in detecting trafficking crime and and policy makers in developing effective policies and regulations to disrupt these networks.

This research project develops an analytical framework to examine structural patterns and evolution of organ trafficking networks. The framework will: i) deploy an agent-based simulation model to characterize such networks based on limited but reliable data from the field; ii) provide a network analysis to investigate structural connections and their vulnerabilities in the networks; and iii) explore optimization methods to derive effective strategies to disrupt these networks. The impact of properties that distinguish these networks from other illicit supply networks, namely the higher profit per transaction, involvement of highly skilled, often high profile actors (physicians, lab technicians, etc.) and required access to specialized facilities and equipment will be studied as a potential points of leverage.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Project Title: EAGER: ISN: Network Analysis and Opportunities for Disruption of Organ Trafficking 

Federal Award ID:1838306 

 Overview

This project investigated organ trafficking networks, with a focus on the illicit kidney trade. These networks involve multiple actors, including sellers, buyers, brokers, healthcare providers, and financial institutions. Limited research exists on the structures of these networks, which operate through tightly controlled, covert social connections and rely on brokers who facilitate illegal transactions. The project’s primary aim was to map these networks using network analysis.

Intellectual Merit

The project united experts from diverse fields, including transplant physicians, quantitative and qualitative researchers, and behavioral and computer scientists, each bringing unique perspectives to the study of organ trafficking networks. By working collaboratively, the team was able to explore organ trafficking from multiple angles, creating a more comprehensive understanding of the network's structural and operational nuances. This convergence of expertise enabled the project to address challenges specific to organ trafficking that do not commonly appear in other types of illicit networks, such as human or drug trafficking. For instance, organ trafficking networks require coordination among highly skilled individuals (e.g., surgeons and healthcare providers) and access to specialized facilities. The project’s intellectual merit also lies in its approach to uncovering the hidden dimensions of these networks using both quantitative data analysis and qualitative insights. Field research provided depth to the study by revealing social, economic, and ethical factors that contribute to network sustainability. Meanwhile, quantitative methods such as network analysis identified structural vulnerabilities and key network players, especially brokers, whose roles are critical to network cohesion.

Broader Impacts

The ultimate vision behind this project was to establish a strong foundation for a transdisciplinary team to conduct a large-scale, comprehensive investigation organ trafficking. This foundation also aimed to foster ongoing collaboration among international stakeholders, including policymakers, law enforcement, healthcare providers, and researchers, to understand the factors related to effective policies and interventions. Through this project, the team also raised awareness among the global scientific community and to involved professionals across fields through symposiums and workshops. Additionally, the project contributed to the training of several graduate and undergraduate students, who were involved in network modeling, data collection, and analysis. These students gained valuable knowledge needed in interdisciplinary research, thereby strengthening the pipeline of future experts in tackling global health and security challenges.

Outcome

This project offered insights into the structure and operation of global kidney trafficking networks. By integrating field data with information gathered through web scraping, the project mapped the connections between sellers, buyers, and surgery hubs, particularly in regions known for illegal organ trade. Field research in South Asia and Central America highlighted socio-economic drivers behind organ trafficking, such as poverty, limited healthcare access, and demand from wealthier foreign buyers. These findings identified specific hubs where brokers play a pivotal role in coordinating cross-border transactions.

 Through web scraping, the project collected 276 relevant articles, identifying 428 unique transnational kidney trade networks. Analysis revealed regional patterns: sellers from Nepal, Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh often supply kidneys to buyers from Middle Eastern and South Asian countries. Surgery hubs—locations with robust medical infrastructure and minimal enforcement—were primarily found in India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka, where foreign patients can undergo transplants with reduced legal risk.

 Network analysis highlighted the central role of brokers, who facilitate trade between sellers and buyers across multiple regions. These brokers demonstrated adaptability to changing regulations, moving operations as needed to avoid detection.

Finally, the insights generated from this award laid the groundwork for a subsequent project, D-ISN: Evolution of Global Illicit Kidney Trade Networks. This new project will further investigate the network dynamics identified here, allowing for continued development of targeted, impactful policies and interventions against global organ trafficking.

Publications

1. Nielsen, Joshua, Abu Bakkar Siddique, Meng-Hao Li, Monica Gentili, Seán Columb, Guadalupe Correa-Cabrera, and Naoru Koizumi. "Social network analysis of illicit organ trading networks: The Medicus case." Trends in Organized Crime (2023): 1-39.

2. Li, M. H., Siddique, A. B., Wilson, B., Patel, A., El-Amine, H., & Koizumi, N. (2022). Identifying kidney trade networks using web scraping data. BMJ Global Health, 7(9), e009803.

 3. Li, Meng-Hao, Yang Yu, Abu Bakkar Siddique, Narae Lee, Md Reazul Haque, Md Lutfay Tariq Rahman, Manzur Ahmad, Hadi El-Amine, and Naoru Koizumi. "Using the network scale-up method to characterize kidney trafficking in Kalai Upazila, Bangladesh." BMJ global health 8, no. 11 (2023): e012774.

 4. Siddique, A.B., Apte, V., Fry-Revere, S., Jin, Y., and Koizumi, N. “Do Global Reimbursement Programs Increase the Number of Living Organ Donations?", BMJ Global Health, August 2020, 5:e002596


Last Modified: 11/06/2024
Modified by: Naoru Koizumi
